column3: concept ACK, although good point in that thread that currently users would have no way of replacing this transaction with something non-replaceable. I suppose this doesn't matter much until a release however.
Probably shouldn't be merged until something can actually use it (preferably from the GUI).
@instagibbs, I added an option to create non-replaceable bumpfee transactions in 8d3cd2844b844cad92d741d848ee0ffebdffef40.
Concept ACK
Also related: #9519

I was supportive of bip125 because it was marketed, sold and even titled: "Opt-in". But this simple change in defaults really makes it "Opt-out" and will end up causing huge impacts to people who are currently relying on 0-conf transactions, as suddenly everyone is going to be accidentally sending "opt-in" RBF.\n\nFor what it's worth, I've tried using bip125 for "fee bumping" but it pretty much

@RHavar has a point too. Maybe some day it will make sense to enable it by default, but today is probably not that. Instead, let's focus on 1) making it do something actually useful; and then 2) allowing users to enable it on a per-transaction basis (we can also let them change the default in the GUI options).

> I was supportive of bip125 because it was marketed, sold and even titled: "Opt-in". But this simple change in defaults really makes it "Opt-out" and will end up causing huge impacts to people who are currently relying on 0-conf transactions, as suddenly everyone is going to be accidentally sending "opt-in" RBF.\n\nBitcoin Core is a relatively small wallet when it comes to consumer transactions.

> This seems strange. The min relay fee you should have to pay is relatively small. Are you looking at relay or are you looking at mining-time? (Many pools currently lose a few tens or hundreds of dollars by still not mining Opt-in RBF).\n\nNot really. You don't need to pay just an extra "min relay fee", you need to pay transaction fees on the size of the old + new transaction. So if you're repl

> What am I missing? If you're replacing a transaction with a transaction the same size (which is the general case) the network will not propagate any replacement transaction that doesn't pay at least >= 2x the fee\n\nNo, the network will not propagate a transaction which does not pay at least the "min relay fee" in addition to the previous transaction's fee. The "min relay fee" is currently defau

> Not really. You don't need to pay just an extra "min relay fee", you need to pay transaction fees on the size of the old + new transaction. So if you're replacing a transaction with a transaction the same size (which is the general case) the network will not propagate any replacement transaction that doesn't pay at least >= 2x the fee.\n\nNo you don't? You have to pay only 1000 satoshis per KB t

> No you don't? You have to pay only 1000 satoshis per KB to cover the old, and meet network fee for the new transaction.

Oh god. Seems like I misread the bip and have been massively overpaying for my RBF =/  Ok, that's my fault. I'm a retard. I take back my claims of RBF being crappy and will apply that to my reading comprehension.

I apologize for derailing this with my own stupidity.

I read the BIP text differently from you, I suppose (and mine meets the implementation, and also if it were to work the way you claim, I agree it'd be very useless). Probably means the BIP text needs clarification :).

On January 12, 2017 10:22:44 PM PST, Ryan Havar <notifications@github.com> wrote:
>> No, the network will not propagate a transaction which does not pay
>at least the "min relay
General Concept ACK.\nI think this should not be merge before we have a bumpfee option accessible over the GUI, otherwise there are little reasons why to enable this for pure GUI users.

@RHavar  The reading may be more clear to some due to understanding the motivation: The reason it works the way it does is so that RBF doesn't allow an attacker to use any more relay bandwidth than they could use without RBF (e.g. creating additional transactions at the minrelayfee rate). So that means that every bump just needs to increase by the minimum rate that would have caused relay-- the ra

I do think we should eventually make this the default.
I'm ambivalent about whether we do it now or not.
I do think the release notes, and possibly the help for bumpfee should make it clear you need to explicitly set walletrbf in order to have transactions that you could apply bumpfee to if we don't change the default.

@jonasschnelli there is still a ton of value in being able to respond to user complaints with "OK, copy txid from transaction inspector, then type bumpfee $TXID in the debug window".

On January 13, 2017 7:18:37 AM PST, Alex Morcos <notifications@github.com> wrote:
>I do think we should eventually make this the default.
>I'm ambivalent about whether we do it now or not.
>I do think the releas

> @jonasschnelli there is still a ton of value in being able to respond to user complaints with "OK, copy txid from transaction inspector, then type bumpfee $TXID in the debug window".

Thats true.
But maybe new conplaints will appear (non final nSequence can lead to merchants rejects during confirmation phase).

IMO before merging this we should:
* have bumpfee in RPC (ideally in the
I don't think BIP125 should be enabled by default - it seems like it should be something the user can choose for individual transactions.
Even if this could render useful in 0.14 with bumpfee, I am worried a policy change this close to a release causes more issues than it solves.\n\nConcept NACK

I created a PR adding an RBF checkbox to the GUI in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9592. That change, while minor, probably should not be merged until after the feature freeze. This change might make more sense after that one.
Needs rebase (if we still want this.)
concept ACK\n

Rebased 700af943fe08cd0491875e4cb0b09fcf49e549e1 -> 02b059dd6a609f1a18a9acc5fe383ee90c4b8a85 ([pr/walletrbf.0](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/commits/pr/walletrbf.0) -> [pr/walletrbf.1](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/commits/pr/walletrbf.1))
ACK https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/02b059dd6a609f1a18a9acc5fe383ee90c4b8a85
ACK https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9527/commits/02b059dd6a609f1a18a9acc5fe383ee90c4b8a85

If this is going to be the default, it seems that `bumpfee` first at least be able to handle all transactions (e.g. ones without change)?  Otherwise it seems a bit premature to be making transactions replaceable that can't even be replaced (and pushes the complexity of detecting and understanding that distinction onto users).
rebase needed.\n\n@RHavar I don't see the logic in having ~zero ability to update fee versus some. Users don't learn about this feature until they're burned.

Rebased 02b059dd6a609f1a18a9acc5fe383ee90c4b8a85 -> ea282da6da3fbf8c2892f41cf1b8f9d973f3facd ([pr/walletrbf.1](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/commits/pr/walletrbf.1) -> [pr/walletrbf.2](https://github.com/ryanofsky/bitcoin/commits/pr/walletrbf.2))\n

@instagibbs because this feature comes with significant negative repercussions. At the moment merchants can (and do) accept 0-conf transaction if they take adequate precautions, such as making sure the transaction fully propagates and has a decent mining fee. (It's even used in risky businesses like casinos, where a double-spend success rate of 1% would be enough to be profitable).\n\nUsing bip1

@RHavar Currently rather than forcing people to wait a confirmation users are essentially forced to wait 2 weeks, or play games importing keys and hoping to find nodes that accept double-spends. `bumpfee` even has a way of turning off the bip125 flag for this very purpose you bring up.\n\nNot going to re-litigate RBF history on this PR as that is off-topic.

> @RHavar Currently rather than forcing people to wait a confirmation users are essentially forced to wait 2 weeks\n\nOf 168049 sends I've made with bitcoin core, using default (*and often lower*) fees, the longest time to confirm has been 5 hours and 48 minutes. Obviously that's a rather horrible experience, but it's been extremely rare (and the fee estimation in 0.15 is set to be a lot more re

As this stays a controversial topic (woohoo, what is not in bitcoin...) for now I think adding the option on a per-spend basis is preferable. This is already the case for RPC (since #9672) and the GUI (in #9592).

Users can be incentivized to enable it by lower fees - as done in #10589. Lower fee estimates can be used when there is the possibility to bump it later.

As further defaults dis
#11605 would enable RBF by default, only for QT and only if the `-walletrbf` flag isn't present.\n\nThanks @ryanofsky for linking to this PR; I wasn't aware of this discussion.
